'''Reverse logistics''' is for all operations related to the reuse of products and materials. It is "the process of moving [[good (economics)|goods]] from their typical final destination for the purpose of capturing value, or proper disposal. [[Remanufacturing]] and [[Refurbishment (electronics)|refurbishing]] activities also may be included in the definition of reverse logistics."<ref>Hawks, Karen. [http://www.rlmagazine.com/edition01p12.php "What is Reverse Logistics?"], ''Reverse Logistics Magazine'', Winter/Spring 2006.</ref> Growing green concerns and advancement of green supply chain management concepts and practices make it all the more relevant.<ref>Srivastava, Samir K. "Network Design for Reverse Logistics", ''Omega'', '''2008''', 36(4), 535-548.</ref> The number of publications on the topic of reverse logistics have increased significantly over the past two decades. The first use of the term "reverse logistics" in a publication was by James R. Stock in a White Paper titled "Reverse Logistics," published by the Council of Logistics Management in 1992.<ref>James R. Stock, Reverse Logistics (Oak Brook, IL: Council of Logistics Management, 1992)</ref> The concept was further refined in subsequent publications by Stock (1998) in another Council of Logistics Management book, titled Development and Implementation of Reverse Logistics Programs,<ref>James R. Stock, Development and Implementation of Reverse Logistics Programs (Oak Brook, IL: Council of Logistics Management, 1998)</ref> and by Rogers and Tibben-Lembke (1999) in a book published by the Reverse Logistics Association titled Going Backwards: Reverse Logistics Trends and Practices.<ref>Dale S. Rogers and Ronald S. Tibben-Lembke, Going Backwards: Reverse Logistics Trends and Practices (Reno, NV: Reverse Logistics Executive Council, 1999)</ref> The reverse logistics process includes the management and the sale of surplus as well as returned equipment and machines from the hardware leasing business. Normally, [[logistics]] deal with events that bring the product towards the customer. In the case of reverse logistics, the resource goes at least one step back in the [[supply chain]]. For instance, goods move from the customer to the distributor or to the manufacturer.<ref>Rengel, P. & Seydl, C. (May 2002). [http://www.seydl.eu/en/papers/Rengel_Seydl_Reverse_Logistics_2002_23_05_en.pdf Completing the Supply Chain Model] at seydl.edu. Retrieved on 2008-04-25.</ref>
When a manufacturer's product normally moves through the [[supply chain network]], it is to reach the distributor or customer. Any process or management after the delivery of the product involves reverse logistics. If the product is defective, the customer would return the product. The manufacturing firm would then have to organise shipping of the defective product, testing the product, dismantling, repairing, recycling or disposing the product. The product would travel in reverse through the supply chain network in order to retain any use from the defective product. The logistics for such matters is reverse logistics.
==Business implications== In today's marketplace, many retailers treat merchandise returns as individual, disjointed transactions. "The challenge for retailers and vendors is to process returns at a proficiency level that allows quick, efficient and cost-effective collection and return of merchandise. Customer requirements facilitate demand for a high standard of service that includes accuracy and timeliness. It’s the logistic company's responsibility to shorten the link from return origination to the time of resell."<ref>Harrington, Ryan. [http://www.rlmagazine.com/edition01p14.php "Reverse Logistics: Customer Satisfaction, Environment Key to Success in the 21st Century"], ''Reverse Logistics Magazine''. Winter/Spring 2006.</ref> By following returns management best practices, retailers can achieve a returns process that addresses both the operational and customer retention issues associated with merchandise returns.<ref>Greer, 2004</ref> Further, because of the connection between reverse logistics and customer retention, it has become a key component within Service Lifecycle Management (SLM), a [[business strategy]] aimed at retaining customers by bundling even more coordination of a company's services data together to achieve greater efficiency in its operations.
Reverse logistics is more than just returns management, it is "activities related to returns avoidance, gatekeeping, disposal and all other [[Aftermarket (automotive)|after-market]] supply chain issues".<ref>Rogers, 2002</ref> Returns management—increasingly being recognized as affecting competitive positioning—provides an important link between marketing and logistics. The broad nature of its cross-functional impact suggests that firms would benefit by improving internal integration efforts. In particular, a firm's ability to react to and plan for the influence of external factors on the returns management process is improved by such internal integration.<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.dea.univr.it/jsp/visualizzaAllegato.jsp?id=26331&mime=application%2Fpdf&filename=Russo+Supply+chain+strategy+IJPDLM.pdf&localname=allegatooa_26331.pdf|title=The returns management process in supply chain strategy | last1= Mollenkopf |first1= D.| last2= Russo |first2= I. |first3= R. |last3= Frankel |journal=International Journal Physical Distribution Logistics Management |volume= 37 |issue= 7 |year= 2007 |pages= 568–92 |accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref> In a firm's planning for returns, a primary factor is the remaining value of the material returning and how to recover that value.<ref>Srivastava, Samir K. "Value Recovery Network Design for Product Returns", ''International Journal of Physical Distribution and Logistics Management'', '''2008''', 38(4), 311-331.</ref> "Returned goods, or elements of the product, could even be returned to suppliers and supply chain partners for them to re-manufacture".<ref>Madaan, J. & Wadhwa, S. (2007) ''Flexible Process Planning Approaches for Sustainable Decisions in Reverse Logistics System'', Global Journal of Flexible Systems Management. Vol. 8, No. 4. p. 1-8</ref>
[[Third-party logistics]] providers see that up to 7% of an enterprise's gross sales are captured by return costs. Almost all reverse logistics contracts are customized to fit the size and type of company contracting. The [[Third-party_logistics|3PL]]'s themselves realize 12% to 15% profits on this business.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/2005/11/02/returns-reverse-logistics-market-cx_rm_1103returns.html | first= Robert | last= Malone |title= Reverse side of logistics: The business of returns |work=Forbes |date=3 November 2005 | accessdate= 2008-03-14 }}</ref>
"Studies have shown that an average of 4% to 6% of all retail purchases are returned, costing the industry about $40 billion per year." <ref>Van Riper, Tom. [https://archive.is/20130102150110/http://www.forbes.com/2005/12/06/retailing-wal-mart-cx_tvr_1207reselling.html "Reseller Sees Many Happy Returns"], ''Forbes'', December 2005.</ref>
Reverse logistics research has also found that 84.6 percent of companies in the United States use secondary market and 70 percent see the secondary market as a "competitive advantage."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Reverse Logistics Sustainability Council |url=http://www.reverselogistics.com/ "Secondary Market Research" |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
==Return of unsold goods== In certain industries, goods are distributed to downstream members in the supply chain with the understanding that the goods may be returned for credit if they are not sold e.g., newspapers and magazines. This acts as an incentive for downstream members to carry more stock, because the risk of obsolescence is borne by the upstream supply chain members. However, there is also a distinct risk attached to this logistics concept. The downstream member in the supply chain might exploit the situation by ordering more stock than is required and returning large volumes. In this way, the downstream partner is able to offer high level of service without carrying the risks associated with large inventories. The supplier effectively finances the inventory for the downstream member. It is therefore important to analyze customers’ accounts for hidden costs.
==Reusable packaging== [[File:Woda.mineralna.w.skrzynkach.jpg|thumb|upright|Reusable [[mineral water]] bottles in crates]] [[Reusable packaging]] systems require a [[Circular economy|closed-loop]] logistics system. Examples include reusable [[pallet]]s, [[Bulk_box|bulk boxes]] such as [[Euro container]]s, [[reuse of bottles|Reusable bottles]] for milk, soda, and beer, compressed gas cylinders, beer kegs, etc.
==Refusal of the products in the cash on delivery (COD)== In case of [[e-commerce]] business, many websites offer the flexibility of [[cash on delivery]] (COD) to their customers. Sometimes customers refuse the product at the time of delivery, as there is no commitment to take the product. Then the logistics service provider follows the process of reverse logistics on the refused cargo. It is also known as Return to Origin (RTO). In this process, the e-commerce company adds the refused cargo to its inventory stock again, after proper quality checks as per the company's rules.<ref>{{cite book| title= Business Logistics & Management - Theory and Practice |first1= J J |last1= Vogt| first2=W J |last2= Pienaar |first3=P W C |last3= de Wit | publisher= OXFORD |year= 2002 |page= 236 }}</ref>
==Reverse Logistics for Demonstrations== In case of the Demonstration of Products to the client as part of Pre-Sales process, The Demonstration equipment is sent to the Customer and has to be returned to maintain Revolving Inventory.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hollingsworthllc.com/guide-reverse-logistics/ Glossary of the Reverse Logistics Executive Council]

Many nations have installed significant [[solar power]] capacity into their electrical grids to supplement or provide an alternative to [[conventional energy]] sources. Solar power plants use one of two technologies: * [[Photovoltaic]] (PV) [[Photovoltaic systems|systems]] use [[solar panel]]s, either on [[Rooftop photovoltaic power station|rooftops]] or in ground-mounted [[solar farm]]s, converting sunlight directly into electric power. * [[Concentrated solar power]] (CSP, also known as "concentrated solar thermal") plants use [[solar thermal energy]] to make steam, that is thereafter converted into electricity by a turbine. Worldwide [[growth of photovoltaics]] is extremely dynamic and varies strongly by country. By the end of 2016, cumulative photovoltaic capacity increased by more than 75 [[gigawatt]] (GW) and reached at least 303 GW, sufficient to supply approximately 1.8 percent of the world's total [[electricity consumption]]. The top installers of 2016 were [[#China|China]], the [[#United States|United States]], and [[#India|India]].[https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/iea-global-installed-pv-capacity-leaps-to-303-gw IEA: Global Installed PV Capacity Leaps to 303 Gigawatts], greentechmedia, Eric Wesoff, April 27, 2017 There are more than 24 countries around the world with a cumulative PV capacity of more than one gigawatt. [[#Austria|Austria]], [[#Chile|Chile]], and [[#South Africa|South Africa]], all crossed the one gigawatt-mark in 2016. The available solar PV capacity in Honduras is now sufficient to supply 12.5% of the nation's electrical power while [[#Italy|Italy]], Germany and [[#Greece|Greece]] can produce between 7% and 8% of their respective domestic electricity consumption.[http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2016__1_.pdf 2016 Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets], International Energy Agency, 2017{{cite web |title = Global Market Outlook for Solar Power 2015-2019 |url = http://www.solarpowereurope.org/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Publications/Global_Market_Outlook_2015_-2019_lr_v23.pdf |website = www.solarpowereurope.org |publisher = Solar Power Europe (SPE), formerly known as EPIA – European Photovoltaic Industry Association |accessdate = 9 June 2015 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6ZA1o2aLo?url=http://www.solarpowereurope.org/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Publications/Global_Market_Outlook_2015_-2019_lr_v23.pdf |archivedate = 9 June 2015 |deadurl = yes |df = }}{{cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/technical/PVPS_report_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2014.pdf|title=Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2014|date=30 March 2015|website=www.iea-pvps.org|publisher=International Energy Agency — Photovoltaic Power Systems Programme|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XPpb1fai?url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=92&eID=dam_frontend_push&docID=2430|archivedate=30 March 2015|deadurl=no}} After an almost two decade long hiatus, [[Concentrated solar power#Deployment around the world|deployment of CSP]] resumed in 2007. However, the design for several new projects is being changed to cheaper photovoltaics.{{cite web |url=http://cleantechnica.com/2014/02/27/csp-fallen-wayside-may-come-back-big-2020/ |title=CSP Has Fallen By The Wayside – But May Come Back Big By 2020 |website=CleanTechnica |date=27 February 2014}} Most [[List of solar thermal power stations|operational CSP stations]] are located in [[#Spain|Spain]] and the United States, while [[List of photovoltaic power stations|large solar farms]] using photovoltaics are being constructed in an expanding list of geographic regions. As of January 2017, the largest solar power plants in the world are the 850 MW [[Longyangxia Dam Solar Park]] in China for PV and the 377 MW [[Ivanpah Solar Power Facility]] in the United States for CSP. {{Horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}} == Global deployment figures == ===Solar PV=== {{see also|Growth of photovoltaics}} {| style="margin: 1px auto;float:right" |- | {{Image frame |width = 300 |align = center |pos = top |content =

Country !! Total !! Added |- | align=left|{{flag|Spain}} || 2,300 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|United States}} || 1,738 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|India}} || 225 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|South Africa}} || 200 || 100 |- | align=left|{{flag|Morocco}} || 180 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|United Arab Emirates}} || 100 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|Algeria}} || 25 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|Egypt}} || 20 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|Australia}} || 12 || 0 |- | align=left|{{flag|China}} || 10 || 10 |- | align=left|{{flag|Thailand}} || 5 || 0 |- ! colspan=3 style="font-size: 0.85em; text-align: left; padding: 6px 0 4px 2px; font-weight: normal;" | ''Source'': [[REN21]] Global Status Report, June, 2017[http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/170607_GSR_2017_Full_Report.pdf Renewables Global Status Report], REN21, 2017 |} == Africa == {{Main|Solar power in Africa}} Many African countries receive on average a very high amount of days per year with bright sunlight, especially the dry areas, which include the deserts (such as the [[Sahara]]) and the steppes (such as the [[Sahel]]).[http://userwww.sfsu.edu/~ciotola/solar/asn_94nuclear.html Solar Power in Africa], National Solar Power Research Institute, Yansane A. 2007 This gives solar power the potential to bring energy to virtually any location in Africa without the need for expensive large scale grid level infrastructural developments. The distribution of solar resources across Africa is fairly uniform, with more than 85% of the continent's landscape receiving at least 2,000 kWh/(m² year). A recent study indicates that a solar generating facility covering just 0.3% of the area comprising North Africa could supply all of the energy required by the [[European Union]].[http://www.trecers.net/downloads/med-csp_en.pdf Report on Solar Power Potential] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927023047/http://www.trecers.net/downloads/med-csp_en.pdf |date=2007-09-27 }}, German Aerospace Center === Algeria === {{main|Solar power in Algeria}} === Morocco === {{main|Solar power in Morocco}} Solar power in Morocco is enabled by the country having one of the highest rates of solar [[insolation]] among other countries— about 3,000 hours per year of sunshine but up to 3,600 hours in the desert. [[Morocco]] has launched one of the world’s largest solar energy projects costing an estimated $9 billion. The aim of the project is to create 2,000 megawatts of solar generation capacity by the year 2020.[http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-16983-afdb-helps-fund-144bn-moroccan-solar-project/ AfDB helps fund $1.44bn Moroccan solar project] Five solar power stations are to be constructed, including both [[photovoltaic]] and [[concentrated solar power]] technology. The Moroccan Agency for Solar Energy (MASEN), a public-private venture, has been established to lead the project. The first plant will be commissioned in 2015,[http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770 Morocco Building 500 MW Solar Power Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924062425/http://ecogeek.org/component/content/article/3770 |date=2014-09-24 }} and the entire project in 2020. Once completed, the solar project will provide 38% of Morocco’s annual electricity generation. === Somalia === {{main|Solar power in Somalia}} === South Africa === {{main|Solar power in South Africa}} South Africa had 1329 MW of PV installations and 100 MW of concentrating solar thermal at the end of 2016. It is expected to reach an installed capacity 8,400 MW by 2030, along with 8,400 MW of [[wind power]].[http://www.evwind.es/noticias.php?id_not=17693 Solar energy in South Africa] The country's insolation greatly exceeds the average values in Europe, Russia, and most of North America.[http://www.solarstreetscapes.com/gallery79052.cfm?startrow=9 Insolation maps, retrieved April 14, 2012] == Asia == === China === {{main|Solar power in China}} [[File:China Photovoltaics Installed Capacity 2016.png|thumb|China's installed solar PV]] China is leading the world in solar PV generation, with the total installed capacity exceeding 100 GW. China is the world's largest market for both [[photovoltaics]] and [[solar thermal energy]]. and in the last few years, more than half of the total PV additions came from the country. Solar power in the People's Republic of China is one of the biggest industries and the subsidies by the government have helped in bringing down the cost of solar power, not only in China, but the whole world. Three of the top four [[List of photovoltaic power stations|largest photovoltaic power stations]] in operation are located in China, including the world's largest Tengger Desert Solar Park. China also leads the world in [[solar water heating]] with 290 [[GWth]] in operation at the end of 2014, accounting for about 70% of the total world capacity. China's goal is to reach 1,300 GW of Solar Capacity by 2050. === India === [[File:Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission Solarishi.jpg|thumb|National Solar Mission in India]] [[File:India Photovoltaics Installed Capacity.svg|thumb|India's installed solar PV capacity]] {{main|Solar power in India}} India has the world's third fastest expanding solar power program (next only to China & USA). In the year 2017 alone India added a record 9,255 MW of solar power with another 9,627 MW of solar projects under development.https://www.pv-tech.org/news/india-added-9255mw-of-solar-in-2017-bridge-to-india{{Cite news|url=https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/solar-trends-2018-gtm-research#gs.wcf=9TI|title=10 Trends That Will Shape the Global Solar Market in 2018|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theenergycollective.com/tim-buckley/2423742/cheap-renewables-transforming-global-electricity-business|title=Cheap Renewables Are Transforming the Global Electricity Business - The Energy Collective|date=2018-02-16|work=The Energy Collective|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en-GB}} India launched its [[Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission|National Solar Mission]] in 2010 under the National Action Plan on Climate Change, with plans to generate 20 GW by 2022. This target has been achieved four years ahead of its deadline with India surpassing 20 GW of installed solar capacity in January 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesstoday.in/current/economy-politics/india-achieves-20-gw-solar-capacity-goal-4-years-ahead-deadline/story/269266.html|title=India achieves 20 GW solar capacity goal four years ahead of deadline|website=www.businesstoday.in|access-date=2018-02-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2018/02/07/india-achieves-20-gigawatts-solar-capacity-4-years-ahead-initial-target/|title=India Achieves 20 Gigawatts Solar Capacity 4 Years Ahead Of Initial Target {{!}} CleanTechnica|website=cleantechnica.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ibef.org/news/india-to-reach-20-gw-of-installed-solar-capacity-by-fy18end-report|title=India to reach 20 GW of installed solar capacity by FY18-end: report|accessdate=22 September 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://mnre.gov.in/mission-and-vision-2/achievements/|title=Physical Progress (Achievements)|publisher=Ministry of New and Renewable Energy, Govt. of India.|accessdate=22 September 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160912041226/http://www.mnre.gov.in/mission-and-vision-2/achievements|archivedate=12 September 2016|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/indias-installed-solar-capacity-reached-6000-mw-in-6-years-manufacturer/articleshow/52447396.cms|title=India's installed solar capacity reached 6,000 MW in 6 years|author=|date=26 May 2016|work=news|publisher=The Economic Times of India|accessdate=27 May 2016}} In January 2015, Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] announced an initiative to increase the solar capacity to 100 GW{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/india-solar/indias-modi-raises-solar-investment-target-to-100-bln-by-2022-idUSL3N0UG13H20150102|title=India's Modi raises solar investment target to $100 bln by 2022|date=2015-01-02|work=Reuters|accessdate=2018-02-04}} and total renewable power capacity to 175 gigawatts (GW) by 2022. This target is ambitious considering the worldwide installed solar capacity at that time was 177 GW, out of which only 2.5 GW was installed in India. To reach the goal of 100 GW of installed solar capacity by 2022, Modi's government has set a target to auction at least 77 gigawatts of additional solar power capacity by March 2020.{{Cite web|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/11/13/india-plans-worlds-largest-solar-power-tender-20-gigawatts/|title=India Plans World’s Largest Solar Power Tender -- 20 Gigawatts {{!}} CleanTechnica|website=cleantechnica.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-04}} A total of 1.2 GW of solar power is tendered in the first week of 2018 and a solar power tender of 20 GW, world's largest so far, is to be auctioned off in one go in 2018. Several large grid-scale solar parks are in operation, several of which are among the [[List of photovoltaic power stations#World's largest photovoltaic power stations|world's largest]] such as [[Kurnool Ultra Mega Solar Park]] with the capacity of 1,000 MW, the Kamuthi Solar Power Project with the capacity of 648 MW, the 345 MW [[Charanka Solar Park]], the 480 MW [[Bhadla Solar Park]] with a proposed capacity of 2,255 MW and the [[Gujarat]] solar parks with a combined capacity of 605 MW.[http://www.energyinsight.info/gujarat_charanka_solar_park.html Gujarat's Charanka Solar Park] In July 2017, Indian Railways rolled out trains with rooftop solar to power the lights, fans and displays inside the coaches.{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/1030696/india-is-rolling-out-trains-with-solar-powered-coaches-thatll-save-thousands-of-litres-of-diesel/|title=India is rolling out trains with solar-powered coaches that’ll save thousands of litres of diesel|last=Ghoshal|first=Devjyot|work=Quartz|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/india-solar-panel-train-power-cut-diesel-use-renewable-energy-delhi-india-railways-jackson-engineers-a7848286.html|title=India launches solar-panelled train that will save 21,000 litres of diesel a year|date=2017-07-19|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en-GB}} Cochin International Airport, seventh busiest in India, is the first one in the world to run entirely on solar power,{{Cite journal|date=2017-07-01|title=Fully solar powered airport: A case study of Cochin International airport|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0969699717300297|journal=Journal of Air Transport Management|language=en|volume=62|pages=176–188|doi=10.1016/j.jairtraman.2017.04.004|issn=0969-6997}}{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/03/14/technology/india-cochin-solar-powered-airport/index.html|title=The first world's first solar-powered airport is in Cochin, India|last=Mullen|first=Jethro|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-02-06}} handling more than 1,000 flights a week. Similarly, the Union Territory of Diu is fully run by solar power.{{Cite news|url=https://www.care2.com/causes/indian-district-becomes-first-union-territory-to-run-entirely-on-solar-power.html|title=Indian District Becomes First Union Territory to Run Entirely on Solar Power {{!}} Care2 Causes|work=Care2 Causes|access-date=2018-03-18|language=en-US}} Solar power features prominently in Modi government’s USD $2.5 billion SAUBHAGYA scheme launched in July 2015 to electrify every Indian household by 2019 — a huge task considering around 300 million people were without electricity. The use of local mini-grids run on solar power is “a big part of the push, with 60 percent of new connections expected to be to renewable power", according to a report by the International Energy Agency.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-solarpower-women/solar-power-push-lights-up-options-for-indias-rural-women-idUSKBN1FW0LI|title=Solar power push lights up options for India’s rural women|date=2018-02-12|work=Reuters|accessdate=2018-02-18}} The government provides subsidy of up to 90% of the upfront capital cost to install solar-powered water pumping systems for irrigation and drinking water.[32] As of 30 November 2017, more than 142,000 solar pumps have been installed to irrigate the agricultural fields.[33] This scheme weans farmers away from diesel-powered pumps and generates extra income for them by allowing to sell surplus power to the grid. It is one of the innovative ways that the government is empowering the rural population with the help of solar energy by addressing specific issues such as water availability. The solar panels are being built over the irrigation canals to preserve water from evaporation in drought-prone sunny areas. The world's first canal-top solar project was set up on Narmada in Gujarat in 2012. For the last mile connectivity in remote and inaccessible areas, the government provides solar power packs of 200 to 300 watt-peak (Wp), along with battery bank, that includes five LED lights, one DC fan and one DC power plug.[34] Other schemes includes Solar Street Light Scheme, providing solar direct current lighting systems, solar lanterns, solar cookers, etc. In January 2016, the Prime Minister of India, [[Narendra Modi]], and the former President of France, [[François Hollande]], laid the foundation stone for the headquarters of the [[Sunshine countries|International Solar Alliance]] (ISA) in Gwalpahari, India, an alliance of 121 countries, announced at the Paris COP21 climate summit.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/pm-narendra-modi-and-french-president-francois-hollande-to-launch-game-changing-solar-alliance/articleshow/49975568.cms|title=PM Narendra Modi and French President Francois Hollande to launch game changing solar alliance|last=Goswami|first=Urmi|date=2015-11-30|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-02-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/international-solar-alliance-sign-of-indias-leadership-on-global-stage-say-experts-2528060.html|title=International Solar Alliance sign of India's leadership on global stage, say experts - Firstpost|website=www.firstpost.com|access-date=2018-02-11}} The [[International Solar Alliance|ISA]] focuses on promoting and developing solar energy and reducing production and development costs through wider deployment of solar technologies in the developing world.{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/environment/india-unveils-global-solar-alliance-120-countries-paris-climate-summit|title=India Unveils Global Solar Alliance of 120 Countries at Paris Climate Summit|last=Neslen|first=Arthur|date=2015-12-04|newspaper=AlterNet|access-date=2016-08-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/world/paris-climate-meet-indialed-global-solar-alliance-to-counter-developed-nations/article7916353.ece|title=Paris climate meet: India-led global solar alliance to counter developed nations|work=@businessline|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en}} On June 30, 2016, the alliance entered into a partnership with the [[World Bank]] for accelerating mobilization of finance for solar energy — an estimated US $1000 billion in investments that will be needed by 2030, to meet [[International Solar Alliance|ISA]]'s goals for the massive deployment of affordable solar energy worldwide.{{Cite journal|date=2018-02-08|title=International Solar Alliance|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=International_Solar_Alliance&oldid=824635682|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} At the World Future Energy Summit (WFES) held in Abu Dhabi in January 2018, the government of India announced the setting up of a $350 million solar development fund to enable financing of solar projects. Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] promoted solar energy during the plenary speech at [[World Economic Forum]] annual meet in Davos in 2018 and invited investments in the sector in India promising ease of doing business.{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/zoGD1tD80dF755GW9xZkyJ/Narendra-Modi-in-Davos-LIVE-PM-to-address-World-Economic-Fo.html|title=WEF Davos 2018 highlights: Narendra Modi warns of three global threats|last=Livemint|date=2018-01-23|work=http://www.livemint.com/|access-date=2018-02-08}} Modi's ambitious plan when announced in the leading up to the Paris COP21 climate summit received much skepticism and the government's strategy to scale-up the renewable energy by relying on competitive bidding to reduce the cost was regarded as infeasible. However, starting around 2016-2017, new renewable energy became cheaper to build than running existing coal-fired plants in India. As of January 2018, 65% of coal power generation in India is being sold at higher rates than new renewable energy bids in competitive power auctions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/energyinnovation/2018/01/30/india-coal-power-is-about-to-crash-65-of-existing-coal-costs-more-than-new-wind-and-solar/#640dd3104c0f|title=India Coal Power Is About To Crash: 65% Of Existing Coal Costs More Than New Wind And Solar|last=Technology|first=Energy Innovation: Policy and|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}} India has scrapped tenders for coal-fired power stations and around 80% of new coal-fired power plants under planning have been halted or canceled.{{Cite news|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Trends/Renewable-energy-rise-forces-layoffs-at-Mitsubishi-Hitachi-Power|title=Renewable energy rise forces layoffs at Mitsubishi Hitachi Power|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127042701/https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Trends/Renewable-energy-rise-forces-layoffs-at-Mitsubishi-Hitachi-Power|archive-date=2018-01-27|dead-url=yes}} In the month of May 2017 alone, plans for building coal power for nearly 14 GW – about the same as the total amount in the UK – were canceled on account of declining solar costs.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/india-solar-power-electricity-cancels-coal-fired-power-stations-record-low-a7751916.html|title=India just cancelled 14 huge coal-fired power stations as solar energy prices hit record low|date=2017-05-23|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-GB}} Analyst Tim Buckley said “Measures taken by the Indian Government to improve energy efficiency coupled with ambitious renewable energy targets and the plummeting cost of solar has had an impact on existing as well as proposed coal fired power plants, rendering an increasing number as financially unviable. India’s solar tariffs have literally been free falling in recent months."{{Cite web|url=http://ieefa.org/ieefa-asia-indias-electricity-sector-transformation-happening-now/|title=IEEFA Asia: India’s Electricity-Sector Transformation Is Happening Now - Institute for Energy Economics & Financial Analysis : Institute for Energy Economics & Financial Analysis|website=ieefa.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}} As reported by NYTimes in May 2017, "According to research released last week at a United Nations climate meeting in Germany, China and India should easily exceed the targets they set for themselves in the 2015 Paris Agreement..... India is now expected to obtain 40 percent of its electricity from non-fossil fuel sources by 2022, eight years ahead of schedule."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/22/opinion/paris-agreement-climate-china-india.html|title=Opinion {{!}} China and India Make Big Strides on Climate Change|last=Board|first=The Editorial|date=2017-05-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-04|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/coal-india-closes-37-mines-solar-power-sustainable-energy-market-influence-pollution-a7800631.html|title=The world's biggest coal company just shut down 37 mines because they are not economically viable anymore|date=2017-06-21|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en-GB}} === Japan === {{Main|Solar power in Japan}} Solar power in [[Japan]] has been expanding since the late 1990s. By the end of 2017, cumulative installed PV capacity reached over 50 GW with nearly 8 GW installed in the year 2017. The country is a leading manufacturer of solar panels and is in the top 4 ranking for countries with the most solar PV installed. Overall installed capacity is now estimated to be sufficient to supply 2.5% of the nation's annual electricity demand. The [[insolation]] is good at about 4.3 to 4.8 kWh/(m²·day). Japan was the world's [[Growth of photovoltaics|second largest market for solar PV growth]] in 2013 and 2014, adding a record 6.9 GW and 9.6 GW of nominal nameplate capacity, respectively. ===Myanmar=== {{Main|Solar power in Myanmar}} === Pakistan === Pakistan has set up a solar power park, funded by the Chinese company TBEA, in the Cholistan desert near Yazman, about 30 kilometers from the eastern city of Bahawalpur. The solar project, which is set up on 5,000 acres, is producing 100 MW . Another Chinese company, Zonergy is setting up 900MW of Solar Power Plant in the same region. The first unit was completed with a cost of 15 billion rupees in a short period of eleven months. The electricity generated by the project will be added to the national grid through grid stations and power supply transmission lines. Second phase of the park will comprise 900 MW which will be completed with the help of Chinese Government.http://dawn.com/news/1039608/cm-punjab-approves-quaid-e-azam-park-development-plan .http://tribune.com.pk/story/881172/energy-crisis-pm-to-inaugurates-100mw-solar-energy-project .http://www.qasolar.com ===Philippines=== In 2012, the [[Philippines]] generated a modest 1,320 MWh of solar energy.{{Cite web |url=http://www.doe.gov.ph/doe_files/pdf/02_Energy_Statistics/Power-Statistics-2012.pdf |title=PH Power Statistics 2012 |access-date=2015-04-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717042701/https://www.doe.gov.ph/doe_files/pdf/02_Energy_Statistics/Power-Statistics-2012.pdf |archive-date=2015-07-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} === South Korea === {{main|Energy in South Korea}} The [[Sinan solar power plant]] is a 24 MW [[photovoltaic power station]] in [[Sinan, Jeollanam-do]], [[South Korea]]. {{As of|2009}}, it is the largest photovoltaic installation in Asia. The project was developed by the German company [[Conergy]] and it cost US$150 million. It was built by the Dongyang Engineering & Construction Corporation.[http://www.exenewable.com/projectProfile.asp?id=12612 eXenewable Project Profile Page - SinAn, PV, Korea] === Taiwan === {{main|Renewable energy in Taiwan}} The government has a long-term plan to make the solar capacity become 4,500 MW by 2020 and to make 7.5 million Taiwan residents to utilize solar energy by 2030. To give further incentives, the government has designated solar energy and LED industries as two industries to actively develop in the near future. === Thailand === {{Main|Solar power in Thailand}} In 2015, [[Thailand]] has more solar power capacity than all the rest of Southeast Asia combined. Thailand's solar capacity will rise to 2,500-2,800 MW in the end of 2015 from about 1,300 MW in 2014. Thailand aims to increase its solar capacity to 6,000 MW by 2036. That would account for 9% of total electricity generation.[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/07/12/thailand-solar-idUKL3N0ZM2JB20150712 Thailand ignites solar power investment in Southeast Asia] ''[[Reuters]].'' July 12, 2015. Retrieved 2015-07-24. ==Middle East== === Cyprus === {{main|Solar power in Cyprus}} === Georgia === {{main|Solar energy in Georgia (country)}} === Israel === {{main|Solar power in Israel}} [[File:Zin Valley in the Negev Desert of Israel.jpg|thumb|The [[Negev Desert]] is home to the Israeli solar research industry, in particular the [[National Solar Energy Center]] and the [[Arava Valley]], which is the sunniest area of Israel.]] There is no oil on Israeli land and the country's tenuous relations with its oil-rich neighbors (see [[Arab–Israeli conflict]]) has made the search for a stable source of energy a national priority.[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Environment/Solar.html Solar Energy in Israel], [[David Faiman]] for the Jewish Virtual Library.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1222017430932 Bright ideas], Ehud Zion Waldoks, ''[[Jerusalem Post]]'', October 1, 2008. So [[Israel]] has embraced [[solar energy]]. Israeli innovation and research has advanced solar technology to a degree that it is almost cost-competitive with [[fossil fuels]].[http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/mar2008/gb20080326_485582.htm?chan=globalbiz_europe+index+page_companies At the Zenith of Solar Energy], Neal Sandler,''[[BusinessWeek]]'', March 26, 2008. Its abundant sun made the country a natural location for the promising technology. The high amount of sunshine received by the [[Negev Desert]] every year has spurred an internationally renowned solar research and development industry, with [[Arnold Goldman]] (founder of Luz, Luz II and [[BrightSource Energy]]), [[Harry Zvi Tabor|Harry Tabor]] and [[David Faiman]] of the [[National Solar Energy Center]] its more prominent members. At the end of 2008 a [[feed-in tariff]] scheme was approved, which immediately put in motion the building of many residential and commercial solar energy power station projects. Luz and Bright Source R&D centers in Jerusalem pioneered industrial scale solar energy fields with initial installations in California's [[Mojave Desert]]. === Jordan === {{main|Solar power in Jordan}} === Saudi Arabia === {{main|Solar power in Saudi Arabia}} The Saudi agency in charge of developing the nations renewable energy sector, [[Ka-care]], announced in May 2012 that the nation would install 41 gigawatts of solar capacity by 2032, this plan was later was revised to 9.5 GW installed capacity. At the time of this announcement, Saudi Arabia had only 0.003 gigawatts of installed solar energy capacity.Wael Mahdi and Marc Roca. "Saudi Arabia Plans $109 Billion Boost for Solar Power." Bloomberg News. May 11, 2012 9:23 AM CT In 2018 there has been a proposal for a total of 200 GW of solar power capacity by 2030. The newly announced project is estimated to cost $200 billion through 2030.{{cn|date=August 2018}} === United Arab Emirates === {{main|Solar power in United Arab Emirates}} In 2013, the [[Shams solar power station]], a 100 [[megawatt|MW]] [[Concentrated solar power plant]] near [[Abu Dhabi]] became operational. The US$600 million Shams 1 is the largest CSP plant outside the United States and Spain and is expected to be followed by two more stations, Shams 2 and Shams 3.shamspower.ae [http://www.shamspower.ae/en/ Shames-website] === Yemen === {{main|Solar power in Yemen}} == Europe == {{see also|Solar power in the European Union}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 350px;" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 |- | [[File:BedZED 2007.jpg|frameless|203px]] | rowspan=2 | [[File:CIS Tower.jpg|frameless|140px]] |- | [[File:Solar panels on a 1930s semi on Barleyfields Road, Wetherby (31st May 2013).JPG|frameless|203px]] |- | colspan=2 | ''Top-left'': [[solar panel]]s on the [[BedZED]] development in the [[London Borough of Sutton]]. This is mainly due to the strong decline of new installations in some major markets such as [[Solar power in Germany|Germany]] and [[Solar power in Italy|Italy]], while the [[Solar power in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] and some smaller European countries are still expected to break new records in 2014.SolarPowerPortal.co.uk [http://www.solarpowerportal.co.uk/guest_blog/uk_downgraded_to_2.4gw_for_2014_as_roc_uncertainty_bites UK downgraded to 2.4GW for 2014 as ROC uncertainty bites], 1 October 2014 [[Solar power in Spain|Spain]] deployed about 350 MW (+18%) of [[concentrated solar power]] (CSP) in 2013, and remains a [[Concentrated solar power#Deployment around the world|worldwide leader]] of this technology. European countries still account for about 60 percent of worldwide deployed capacity of [[solar power]] in 2013."Worldwide CSP-Solar thermal capacity in 2013: 3,425 megawatts" {{cite web |url = http://www.ren21.net/Portals/0/documents/Resources/GSR/2014/GSR2014_full%20report_low%20res.pdf |title = Renewables 2014: Global Status Report |author = [[REN21]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6SKF06GAX?url=http://www.ren21.net/Portals/0/documents/Resources/GSR/2014/GSR2014_full%20report_low%20res.pdf |archivedate = 4 September 2014 |year = 2014 |page = 51 |format = PDF |deadurl = no |df = }}"Worldwide solar PV capacity in 2013: 138,856 megawatts">{{cite web |title = Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018 |url = http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf |website = www.epia.org |publisher = EPIA - [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association]] |accessdate = 12 June 2014 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf |archivedate = 12 June 2014 |format = PDF |year = 2014 |page = 17 |deadurl = yes |df = }} === Austria === {{main|Solar power in Austria}} Austria had 421.7 MW of [[photovoltaics]] at the end of 2012, 234.5 MW of which was installed that year. Most of it is grid connected.[http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/baro-jdp9.pdf Photovoltaic Barometer] Photovoltaic deployment in Austria had been rather modest for many years, while in other European countries, such as [[Solar power in Germany|Germany]], [[Solar power in Italy|Italy]] or [[Solar power in Spain|Spain]] installations were booming with new records year after year until 2011. The tide has turned in 2012. New PV installations jumped to more than 200 megawatt per year in Austria in an overall declining European solar market. The [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association]] forecasts, that Austria, together with other midsized countries, will contribute significantly to European PV deployment in the coming years.{{cite web|title=Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018|url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|website=www.epia.org|publisher=EPIA - European Photovoltaic Industry Association|accessdate=12 June 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|archivedate=12 June 2014|pages=21, 24, 27, 31|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|df=}} === Belgium === {{main|Solar power in Belgium}} In October 2009, the city of [[Antwerp]] announced that they wanted to install 2,500 m² of [[solar panel]]s on the roofs of public [[building]]s, which would be worth 265,000 [[kWh]] per annum.{{cite web|author=Auteur: ivb |url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF30102009_046 |title=Antwerpen wil 2.500 m² zonnepanelen plaatsen op stadsgebouwen - De Standaard |publisher=Standaard.be |date=2009-10-29 |accessdate=2012-03-10}} In December 2009, [[Katoen Natie]] announced that they would install 800,000 m² of solar panels in various places, including [[Antwerp]].{{cite web|author=Auteur: |url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF05122009_014 |title=Katoen Natie heeft grootste installatie zonnepanelen in Eu... - De Standaard |publisher=Standaard.be |date=2009-12-05 |accessdate=2012-03-10}} It is expected that the installed solar power in the Flemish region will be increased by 25% when finished, resulting in the largest installation in [[Europe]]., the total cost being 166 million euros.{{cite web|url=http://www.demorgen.be/dm/nl/5376/Planet-Watch/article/detail/1038201/2009/12/05/Belgie-heeft-grootste-installatie-zonnepanelen-van-Europa.dhtml |title=België heeft grootste installatie zonnepanelen van Europa - Planet Watch - De Morgen |language=nl |publisher=Demorgen.be |accessdate=2012-03-10}} === Bulgaria === {{main|Solar power in Bulgaria}} Bulgaria had seen a record year in 2012 when its PV capacity multiplied several times over to more than 1 GW. In 2013, however, further deployment came to a halt. === Czech Republic === {{main|Solar power in the Czech Republic}} === Denmark === {{main|Solar power in Denmark}} === Finland === {{main|Solar power in Finland}} === France === {{main|Solar power in France}} === Germany === [[File:Solarfeld Erlasee, 1.jpg|thumb|[[Erlasee Solar Park]]]] {{main|Solar power in Germany}} Germany is among the top 4 ranking countries in terms of installed photovoltaic solar capacity and number one regarding per capita installation of PV. The overall capacity has reached 42.98 [[gigawatts]] (GW) by the end of 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.energy-charts.de/power_inst.htm|title=Installed power in Germany {{!}} Energy Charts|website=www.energy-charts.de|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}}[http://www.bundesnetzagentur.de/DE/Sachgebiete/ElektrizitaetundGas/Unternehmen_Institutionen/ErneuerbareEnergien/Photovoltaik/DatenMeldgn_EEG-VergSaetze/DatenMeldgn_EEG-VergSaetze_node.html Bundesnetzagentur – Photovoltaikanlagen: Datenmeldungen sowie EEG-Vergütungssätze] (in German) Photovoltaics contribute almost 6% to the national electricity demands. Germany has seen an outstanding period of photovoltaic installations from 2010 until 2012. During this boom, about 22 GW, or a third of the worldwide PV installations of that period was deployed in Germany alone. However, the boom period ended in 2012, and Germany's national PV market has since declined significantly, due to the amendments in the [[German Renewable Energy Act]] (EEG) that reduced [[feed-in tariff]]s and set constraints on utility-scaled installations, limiting their size to no more than 10 MW.{{cite web|title=Changes for solar in Germany|url=http://www.renewablesinternational.net/changes-for-solar-in-germany/150/452/77990/|publisher=renewablesinternational.net|accessdate=12 May 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PWAqoX0R?url=http://www.renewablesinternational.net/changes-for-solar-in-germany/150/452/77990/|archivedate=12 May 2014|date=3 April 2014|deadurl=yes|df=}} The current version of the [[German Renewable Energy Act|EEG]] only guarantees financial assistance as long as the overall PV capacity has not yet reached 52 GW. It also foresees to regulate annual PV growth within a range of 2.5 GW to 3.5 GW by adjusting the guaranteed fees accordingly. The legislative reforms stipulates a 40 to 45 percent share from renewable energy sources by 2025 and a 55 to 60 percent share by 2035.[http://www.bmwi.de/DE/Themen/Energie/Erneuerbare-Energien/eeg-reform.html] Large PV power plants in Germany include [[Senftenberg Solarpark]], [[Finsterwalde Solar Park]], [[Lieberose Photovoltaic Park]], [[Strasskirchen Solar Park]], [[Waldpolenz Solar Park]], and [[Köthen Solar Park]]. === Greece === By September 2013, the total installed photovoltaic capacity in Greece had reached 2,523.5 MWp from which the 987.2 MWp were installed in the period between January–September 2013 despite the unprecedented financial crisis.[http://helapco.gr/pdf/pv-stats_greece_18Oct2013.pdf HELAPCO: Total installed capacity January-September 2013] Greece ranks 5th worldwide with regard to per capita installed PV capacity. It is expected that PV produced energy will cover up to 7% of the country's electricity demand in 2014.[http://helapco.gr/en/the-greek-pv-market/ HELAPCO: The Greek PV market] A large solar PV plant is planned for the island of [[Crete]]. Research continues into ways to make the actual solar collecting cells less expensive and more efficient. Smaller solar PV farms exist throughout the country. === Hungary === {{main|Solar power in Hungary}} === Italy === {{main|Solar power in Italy}} Italy added nearly 400 MW of solar PV capacity in the year 2017 reaching a total installed PV capacity of around 19.7 GW.{{Cite news|url=http://www.infobuildenergia.it/notizie/piu13per-cento-installazioni-fotovoltaico-eolico-idro-11-mesi--2017-6057.html|title=+13% le installazioni di fotovoltaico, eolico e idro nei primi 11 mesi del 2017|work=Infobuild Energia|access-date=2018-02-21}} At the end of 2010 there were 155,977 solar PV plants, with a total capacity of 3,469.9 MW.{{cite web|title=Rapporto Statistico 2010|url=http://www.gse.it/attivita/statistiche/Documents/Statistiche%20Rinnovabili%202010.pdf|work=Statistiche sulle fonti rinnovabili|publisher=Gestore Servizi Energetici (GSE)|accessdate=4 January 2012}}{{rp|24}} The number of plants and the total capacity surged in 2009 and 2010 following high incentives from ''Conto Energia''. The total power capacity installed tripled and plants installed doubled in 2010 compared to 2009, with an increase of plant's average dimensions.{{rp|24}} Energy production from photovoltaics was 1,905.7 GWh in 2010. Annual growth rates were fast in recent years: 251% in 2009 and 182% in 2010.{{rp|30}} More than a fifth of the total production in 2010 came from the southern region of [[Apulia]].{{rp|30}} In December 2012, solar PV in Italy provided employment to 100,000 people especially in design and installation.[http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/tecnologie/2012-12-21/incentivi-solare-152027.shtml?uuid=AbUwW9DH Il fotovoltaico in Italia ha una potenza di 17 GW e dà lavoro a 100mila. Quale futuro senza incentivi?] === Lithuania === {{main|Solar power in Lithuania}} === Netherlands === {{main|Solar power in the Netherlands}} === Poland === {{main|Solar power in Poland}} === Portugal === {{main|Solar power in Portugal}} A large [[photovoltaic]] power project, the [[Serpa solar power plant]], has been completed in [[Portugal]], in one of Europe's sunniest areas.[http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/4009836a6026.html Major solar power plant opens in Portugal]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The 11 megawatt plant covers {{convert|150|acre|km2}} and comprises 52,000 PV panels. The panels are raised 2 metres off the ground and the area will remain productive grazing land. The project will provide enough energy for 8,000 homes and will save an estimated 30,000 tonnes of [[carbon dioxide]] emissions per year.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5056012.stm |title=Portugal starts huge solar plant |date=7 June 2006 |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=12 November 2011}}[http://www.geenergyfinancialservices.com/press_room/press_releases/prs_2006_0427.pdf World's largest solar power plant to be built] The [[Moura photovoltaic power station]] is located in the municipality of Moura, in the interior region of Alentejo, Portugal.Its construction involves two stages, with the first one being constructed in 13 months and completed in 2008, and the other will be completed by 2010, at a total cost of €250 million for the project. === Romania === {{main|Solar power in Romania}} Romania has an installed capacity of 1.2 GW as of 2014. Romania is located in an area with a good solar potential of 210 sunny days per year and with an annual solar energy flux between 1,000 kWh/m2/year and 1,300 kWh/m2/year. The most important solar regions of Romania are the Black Sea coast, Dobrogea and Oltenia. === Russia === [[File:Кош-Агач.JPG|thumb|A solar power plant in Russia]] Current production of 5 MW is very modest, however there are plans for an expansion in capacity by 70 MW in 2012-13 in a $210 million joint project by Rosnano and Renova.Предприятия обяжут покупать «зеленую» электроэнергию Вексельберга http://izvestia.ru/news/532219 The development of renewable energy in Russia has been held back by the lack of a conducive framework and government policy.{{Cite book|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/289325179_Russian_renewable_energy_The_potential_for_international_cooperation|title=Russian Renewable Energy – The Potential for International Cooperation|last=Overland|first=Indra|last2=Kjaernet|first2=Heidi|publisher=Asghate|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=}} === Spain === [[File:Foto aére de solnovas y torre junio 2010.jpg|thumb|right|The first three units of [[Solnova Solar Power Station|Solnova]] in the foreground, with the two towers of the [[PS10]] and [[PS20]] solar power stations in the background.]] {{main|Solar power in Spain}} [[Spain]] was an early adopter in the development of solar energy, since it is one of the countries of Europe with more hours of sunshine. The Spanish government committed to achieving a target of 12 percent of primary energy from renewable energy by 2010 with an installed solar generating capacity of 3000 [[megawatts]] (MW).{{cite web | url= http://www.enn.com/energy/article/38265 |title= Spain expects 3,000 MW in solar plants by 2010 |date= September 25, 2008 |work= |publisher= Environmental News Network |accessdate= 2011-03-06 }} Spain is the top tenth in the installed PV solar capacity and used to export 80 percent of solar power output to [[Germany]].{{cite web | url= http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/jun2006/2006-06-30-02.asp | title= Sunny Spain to Host Europe's First Large Solar Thermal Plant |date= June 30, 2006 |publisher= Environment News Service | accessdate= 2011-03-06 }} Total solar power in [[Spain]] reached nearly 7 GW by the end of 2016 including both installed PV and CSP.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ree.es/es/estadisticas-del-sistema-electrico-espanol/series-estadisticas/series-estadisticas-nacionales|title=Red Eléctrica de España {{!}} Series estadísticas nacionales|website=www.ree.es|language=es|access-date=2018-02-06}} Nearly 8 TWh of electricity was generated from photovoltaics, and 5 TWh from CSP plants in 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ree.es/en/statistical-data-of-spanish-electrical-system/statistical-series/national-statistical-series|title=National statistical series {{!}} Red Eléctrica de España|website=www.ree.es|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} Solar PV accounted for nearly 3% of total electricity generation in 2016 along with an additional of 1.9% from solar thermal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=6|title=iea-pvps.org - Annual Reports|website=www.iea-pvps.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} Through a ministerial ruling in March 2004, the Spanish government removed economic barriers to the connection of renewable energy technologies to the electricity grid. The Royal Decree 436/2004 equalized conditions for large-scale [[solar thermal]] and [[photovoltaic]] plants and guaranteed [[Feed-in Tariff|feed-in tariffs]], which led to a boost in solar power adoption in Spain.[http://spider.iea.org/impagr/cip/pdf/issue36solarp.pdf Spain pioneers grid-connected solar-tower thermal power] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927184114/http://spider.iea.org/impagr/cip/pdf/issue36solarp.pdf |date=September 27, 2007 }} In the wake of the [[2008–2009 Spanish financial crisis|2008 financial crisis]], the Spanish government drastically cut its subsidies for solar power and capped future increases in capacity at 500 MW per year leading to a stagnation in the new installations.{{cite news | url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125193815050081615 | title= Spain's Solar-Power Collapse Dims Subsidy Model | first= Angel | last= Gonzalez |author2=Keith Johnson | date= September 8, 2009 | work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate= 2011-03-06 }} === Switzerland === {{main|Solar power in Switzerland}} === Turkey === {{main|Solar power in Turkey}} Registered solar capacity of Turkey stood at 3,420 MW by the end of 2017{{cite web|title=TÜRKİYE ELEKTRİK SİSTEMİ KURULUŞ ve KAYNAKLARA GÖRE KURULU GÜÇ|url=https://www.teias.gov.tr/sites/default/files/2018-01/Kguc2017.pdf|accessdate=5 February 2018}}, although the actual installation can be lower. The increase in registrations mostly happened in December and was attributed to a reduction in feed-in tariffs starting from 2018 (from 0.13 USD to 0.10 USD). === Ukraine === {{main|Solar power in Ukraine}} === United Kingdom === {{main|Solar power in the United Kingdom}} At the end of 2011, there were 230,000 solar power projects in the United Kingdom,{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/02/09/uk-solar-tariff-idUKTRE8180XS20120209 |title=UK wants sustained cuts to solar panel tariffs |author=Yeganeh Torbati |date=Feb 9, 2012 |work=Reuters }} with a total installed generating capacity of 750 [[megawatts]] (MW).{{cite web |url=http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |title=Market Report 2011 |author=European Photovoltaic Industry Association |year=2012 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702040515/http://www.epia.org/index.php?id=18 |archivedate=2014-07-02 |df= }} By February 2012 the installed capacity had reached 1,000 MW.{{cite web |url= |title=UK hits one GW of PV capacity |author=Jonathan Gifford |date=23 February 2012 |work=PV Magazine }} [[Solar power]] use has increased very rapidly in recent years, albeit from a small base, as a result of reductions in the cost of [[photovoltaic]] (PV) panels, and the introduction of a [[Feed-in tariff]] (FIT) subsidy in April 2010. In 2012, the government said that 4 million homes across the UK will be powered by the sun within eight years,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2012/feb/09/solar-power-ambition-uk |title=Greg Barker: 4m homes will be solar-powered by 2020 |author=Fiona Harvey |date=9 February 2012 |work= The Guardian|location=London}} representing 22,000 MW of installed solar power capacity by 2020. As of April 2015, PV capacity had risen to 6,562 MW across 698,860 installations.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/solar-photovoltaics-deployment|title=Gov.UK Statistics - Solar photovoltaics deployment|date=May 28, 2015|author=Department of Energy & Climate Change}} The latest government figures indicates UK solar photovoltaic (PV) generation capacity has reached 12,404 MW in December 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/solar-photovoltaics-deployment|title=Solar photovoltaics deployment - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}} ==Americas== ===Brazil=== {{main|Solar power in Brazil}} ===Canada=== {{main|Solar power in Canada}} [[Sarnia Photovoltaic Power Plant]] near [[Sarnia]], [[Ontario]], was in September 2010 the [[List of photovoltaic power stations|world's largest]] [[photovoltaic plant]] with an [[installed capacity]] of 80 [[Watt-peak|MWp]].[http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2010/10/04/sarnia-enbridge-solar-farm.html Enbridge completes Sarnia solar farm] Retrieved 5 October 2010 until surpassed by a plant in China. The Sarnia plant covers {{convert|950|acre}} and contains about 966,000 square metres (96.6 ha), which is about 1.3 million thin film panels. The expected annual energy yield is about 120,000 MW·h, which if produced in a coal-fired plant would require emission of 39,000 tonnes of CO2 per year. Canada has many regions that are sparsely populated and difficult to access, but also does not have optimal access to sunlight given the high latitudes of much of the country. Photovoltaic cells are increasingly used as standalone units, mostly as off-grid distributed electricity generation to power remote homes, telecommunications equipment, oil and pipeline monitoring stations and navigational devices. The Canadian PV market has grown quickly and Canadian companies make solar modules, controls, specialized water pumps, high efficiency refrigerators and solar lighting systems.{{cite web |title=Another Sunny Year for Solar Power |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725035832/http://worldwatch.org/node/5449 |archivedate=25 July 2011|url=http://worldwatch.org/node/5449}} Ontario has subsidized solar power energy to promote its growth. One of the most important uses for PV cells is in northern communities, many of which depend on high-cost [[diesel fuel]] to generate electricity. Since the 1970s, the federal government and industry has encouraged the development of solar technologies for these communities. Some of these efforts have focused on the use of hybrid systems that provide power 24 hours a day, using solar power when sunlight is available, in combination with another energy source. ===Chile=== {{main|Solar power in Chile}} The 246MW El Romero solar photovoltaic plant open in November 2016 at [[Vallenar]] in the Atacama region[http://en.mercopress.com/2016/11/14/chile-connects-latin-america-s-largest-solar-plant-to-the-national-grid Chile connects Latin America's largest solar plant to the national grid], MercoPress, November 14th 2016 It was the largest solar farm in Latin America when it opened. By the first half of 2015 Chile reached 546 MW of PV installed capacity, and 1,647 MW are under construction.[http://cifes.gob.cl/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/REPORTE_Mayo20151.pdf ERNC report], in ''CIFES'', May 2015 ===Dominican Republic=== {{main|Electricity sector in the Dominican Republic#Solar}} In the Dominican Republic, the Monte Plata Project is the largest operating solar plant in the Caribbean with an installed capacity of 69MW.[http://www.gizmag.com/monte-plata-solar-project-dominican-republic/42572/ Caribbean's largest solar array goes online], gizmag, Stu Robarts, March 31, 2016{{Cite web|url=http://www.gesyw.com/portfolio/project/56d9431a353dc|title=Portfolio - The largest solar project in the Caribbean :: GES - General Energy Solutions|last=Solutions|first=General Energy|website=www.gesyw.com|access-date=2016-06-10}} === Jamaica === {{main|Solar power in Jamaica}} In 2014, a 1.6 MW photovoltaic rooftop system at a seaside resort, located near the parish capital, Lucea in the parish of Hanover, was inaugurated.{{cite web |url=http://jis.gov.jm/government-committed-renewable-energy-agenda/ |title=Government Committed to Renewable Energy Agenda |publisher=Jamaica Information Service |date=9 June 2014}} It was developed by Sofos Jamaica,{{cite web |url=http://www.sofos.es/en/home/ |title=Company homepage |access-date=26 June 2015}} and is the largest in [[Jamaica]] until a 20 MW utility-scale solar PV plant is constructed in the Parish of Clarendon in 2015.{{cite web |url=http://renewables.seenews.com/news/jamaica-shortlists-78-mw-of-wind-solar-capacity-in-govt-tender-381625 |title=Jamaica shortlists 78 MW of wind, solar capacity in govt tender |publisher=seenews.com |date=4 October 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/business/Energy-projects-in-train--set-to-double-renewables-in-Jamaica_17577866 |title=Energy projects in train, set to double renewables in Jamaica |publisher=JamaicaObserver.com |date=21 September 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2015/kw26/wrb-enterprises-signs-usd-47-million-opic-agreement-to-build-a-20-mw-solar-pv-facility-in-jamaica.html |title=WRB Enterprises signs USD 47 million OPIC agreement to build a 20 MW solar PV facility in Jamaica |publisher=solarserver.com |date=26 June 2015 |access-date=2015-06-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701033432/http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2015/kw26/wrb-enterprises-signs-usd-47-million-opic-agreement-to-build-a-20-mw-solar-pv-facility-in-jamaica.html |archive-date=2015-07-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }} No central database yet exists with information on installed capacity but, web searches reveal media articles, press releases and vendor web pages that share some details. Based on these sources up to the middle of 2015, there was over 3.7 MW connected to the grid but, a sizeable portion of that total, including the 1.6 MW rooftop system of a seaside resort{{cite web |url=http://jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Grand-Palladium-Resort-unveils-largest-solar-PV-plant-in-Jamaica |title=Grand Palladium Resort unveils largest solar PV plant in Jamaica |publisher=JamaicaObserver.com |date=1 June 2014 |access-date=2015-06-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626113115/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Grand-Palladium-Resort-unveils-largest-solar-PV-plant-in-Jamaica |archive-date=2015-06-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and a commercial 500 kW-system in the country's capital, [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]],{{cite web |url=http://jamaicaobserver.com/business/Rainforest-invests-US-1m-in-solar-energy_18861183 |title=Rainforest invests US$1m in solar energy |publisher=JamaicaObserver.com |date=3 May 2015}} do not feed power back to the grid despite being interconnected. ===Mexico=== {{main|Solar power in Mexico}} {{update-section|date=April 2015}} Mexico was the greatest solar energy producer in Latin America until passed by Chile. It is planning a [[solar trough]] based plant with 30 MW which will use a [[combined cycle]] gas turbine about 400 MW to provide electricity to the city of Agua Prieta, Sonora. To date, the World Bank has given US$50 million to finance this project. {{cite web |url= http://www.earth-policy.org/datacenter/xls/indicator12_2010_6.xls |title=Cumulative and Newly-Installed Solar Photovoltaics Capacity in Ten Leading Countries and the World, 2009 |author= |publisher=[[Earth Policy Institute]] |date=2010-09-21 |accessdate=2010-09-22}} ===United States=== {{main|Solar power in the United States}} {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align = right |width = 185 |image1=Solar Plant kl.jpg |image2=Barack Obama speaks at Nellis AFB 2009-05-27 2.jpg |caption1=The [[SEGS]] CSS plant in [[San Bernardino County, California]] was built in the 1980s. |caption2=U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] addressed an audience at the [[Nellis Solar Power Plant|Nellis]] in May 2009. }} Solar power in the United States includes utility-scale [[solar power plants]] as well as local [[distributed generation]], mostly from rooftop [[photovoltaics]]. Installations have been growing rapidly in recent years as costs have declined with the U.S. hitting over 50 [[Gigawatt|GW]] of installed solar PV capacity at the end of 2017.{{cite news |url= http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/us-solar-market-sets-new-record-installing-7.3-gw-of-solar-pv-in-2015 |title= US Solar Market Sets New Record, Installing 7.3GW of Solar PV in 2015 |publisher= GTM Research |date= February 22, 2016 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }}{{cite news |url= http://www.seia.org/research-resources/solar-market-insight-2015-q4 |title= Solar Market Insight 2015 Q4 |publisher= [[Solar Energy Industries Association]] |date= March 9, 2016 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} United States is in the top 4 ranking for countries with the most solar PV installed. The American [[Solar Energy Industries Association]] projects that total solar PV capacity will reach over 100 GW by 2021.{{cite news |url= http://www.seia.org/news/us-solar-market-set-grow-119-2016-installations-reach-16-gw |title= Solar Market Set to Grow 119% in 2016, Installations to Reach 16 GW |publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association |date= March 9, 2016 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} Electrical generation has been rising in tandem with capacity as U.S. [[Energy Information Administration]] data show that utility-scale solar power generated 0.65% of total U.S. electricity in 2015, up from 0.01% in 2005.US Energy Information Administration, [http://www.eia.gov/electricity/monthly/epm_table_grapher.cfm?t=epmt_1_1_a Table 1.1.A. Net Generation by Other Renewable Sources: Total (All Sectors), 2005-December 2015], [http://www.eia.gov/electricity/monthly/epm_table_grapher.cfm?t=epmt_1_1 Table 1.1. Net Generation by Energy Source: Total (All Sectors), 2005-December 2015], accessed 11. Mar 2016. This figure is even higher in certain states, already reaching 7% of generation in [[Solar power in California#Generation|California]] for example.{{cite news |url = http://ww2.kqed.org/news/2016/01/11/solar-power-california-top-source-of-renewable-energy |title = Solar Surges Past Wind, Hydro as California's No. 1 Renewable Energy Source |publisher = KQED News |date = January 11, 2016 |accessdate = March 11, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160312064158/http://ww2.kqed.org/news/2016/01/11/solar-power-california-top-source-of-renewable-energy |archive-date = 2016-03-12 |dead-url = yes |df = }}{{cite news |url= http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=24852 |title= California has nearly half of the nation's solar electricity generating capacity |publisher= US Energy Information Administration |date= February 5, 2016 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} The United States conducted much early research in photovoltaics and concentrated solar power and is among the top countries in the world in deploying the technology, [[List of photovoltaic power stations#World's largest photovoltaic power stations|being home to 4 of the 10 largest utility-scale photovoltaic power stations in the world]] as of 2017. The energy resource continues to be encouraged through official policy with 29 states having set mandatory [[Renewable portfolio standard|renewable energy targets]] as of October 2015, solar power being specifically included in 20 of them.{{cite news |url = http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Renewable-Portfolio-Standards.pdf |title = Renewable Portfolio Standard Policies - October 2015 |publisher = Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency |date = October 2015 |accessdate = March 11, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160312073518/http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Renewable-Portfolio-Standards.pdf |archive-date = 2016-03-12 |dead-url = yes |df = }}{{cite news |url = http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/RPS-carveout-map2.pdf |title = Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) with Solar or Distributed Generation Provisions - August 2015 |publisher = Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency |date = August 2015 |accessdate = March 11, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150919071704/http://ncsolarcen-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/RPS-carveout-map2.pdf |archive-date = 2015-09-19 |dead-url = yes |df = }} Aside from utility projects, roughly 784,000 homes and businesses in the nation have installed solar systems through the second quarter of 2015.{{cite news |url= http://www.seia.org/research-resources/solar-industry-data |title= Solar Industry Data |publisher= Solar Energy Industries Association |date= September 2015 |accessdate= March 11, 2016 }} ==Oceania== A number of Pacific island states have committed to high percentages of renewable energy use, both to serve as an example to other countries and to cut the high costs of imported fuels. A number of solar installations have been financed and assisted by Japan, New Zealand and the United Arab Emirates. Solar farms have gone online in [[Renewable energy in Tuvalu|Tuvalu]], [[Fiji]] and [[Kiribati]].[http://www.thenational.ae/business/energy/masdar-and-new-zealand-to-develop-solar-plant-in-solomon-islands Masdar and New Zealand to develop solar plant in Solomon Islands], ''The National'' (Abu Dhabi), October 23, 2015 UAE-Pacific Partnership Fund solar projects completed by [[Masdar]] in 2016 included: 1MW in the [[Solomon Islands]], 500 kW in [[Nauru]], 600 kW in the [[Marshall Islands]], 600 kW in [[Federated States of Micronesia|Micronesia]] and a 450 kW solar-diesel hybrid plant in [[Palau]].[http://www.thenational.ae/business/energy/masdar-completes-five-solar-and-wind-projects-in-the-pacific Masdar completes five solar and wind projects in the Pacific], ''The National'', Abu Dhabi Media, LeAnne Graves, May 17, 2016[https://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395295579132.html UAE-Pacific Partnership Fund accomplishes 11 clean energy projects delivered by Masdar] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160517105738/http://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395295579132.html |date=2016-05-17 }}, Emirates News Agency, 17 May 2016 American Samoa has 2 MW of solar installed at Pago Pago Airport.[http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/279857/american-samoa-embracing-more-solar-power American Samoa embracing more solar power], Radio New Zealand, 28 July 2015 ===Australia=== {{main|Solar power in Australia}} Australia had over 10,131 megawatts (MW) of installed photovoltaic (PV) solar power by September 2018.{{cite web|url=http://pv-map.apvi.org.au/analyses|title=Australian PV market since April 2001|work=apvi.org.au}} The largest solar power station in [[Australia]] is the 220 MW [[Bungala Solar Power Project|Bungala]] solar plant. Other significant solar arrays include the 150 MW Coleambally Solar Farm, 148 MW Ross River Solar Farm, 124 MW [[Sun Metals Solar Farm]] and the 110 MW [[Darling Downs Solar Farm]]. A 9 MWe (megawatts, electrical) solar thermal `coal saver' system was constructed at Liddell power station. The system used `compact linear Fresnel reflector' technology developed in Australia. It provided solar-powered steam to the 600 MW black coal power station's boiler [[feedwater heater]]. By 2016, it was "effectively" closed and an effort to build a similar 40 MW solar boost at Kogan Creek coal power station was stopped.[http://reneweconomy.com.au/2016/cs-energy-pulls-plug-on-worlds-largest-solar-booster-project-16737 CS Energy pulls plug on world's largest "solar booster" project], Renew Economy, Giles Parkinson, 21 March 2016 ===New Zealand=== {{main|Solar power in New Zealand}} Solar power in New Zealand currently only generates 0.1 percent of New Zealand's electricity since more emphasis has been placed on hydroelectric, geothermal, and wind power in New Zealand's push for renewable energy. Solar power systems were installed in 42 schools in New Zealand in the Schoolgen program, a program developed by [[Genesis Energy Limited|Genesis Energy]] to educate students in solar power. Each participating school has a 2 kW solar panel. Between February 2007 and 29 December 29, 2012, 395.714 MWh were produced.[http://www.schoolgen.co.nz/ Schoolgen] In 2010, New Zealand's largest thin film solar array was the 20 kW array installed at Hubbard Foods{{Cite web |url=http://www.hubbards.co.nz/vector.aspx |title=Vector Hubbards Solar Panels |access-date=2013-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208191029/http://hubbards.co.nz/Vector.aspx |archive-date=2013-02-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }} A 21.6 kW photovoltaic array was installed in [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]] in 2009.[http://www.sunnyportal.com/Templates/PublicPageOverview.aspx?plant=796132fc-e1a3-448e-8f43-7c7dee64bc73&splang=en-US Speargrass Domain Plant Profile] In April 2012, New Zealand's largest solar power plant was the 68.4 kW array installed to meet 70% of the electricity needs of South Auckland Forging Engineering Ltd, which is expected to pay for itself in eight to nine years.[http://demm.co.nz/articles/new-zealand%E2%80%99s-largest-solar-power-plant New Zealand's largest solar power plant]Excess power will be purchased at the sale price for two years, otherwise known as net metering. == See also == {{Portal|Energy|Renewable energy}} {{Div col|colwidth=28em}} *[[List of photovoltaic power stations]] *[[List of solar thermal power stations]] *[[Growth of photovoltaics]] *[[Renewable energy]] *[[Renewable energy commercialization]] *[[Solar energy]] *[[Solar thermal energy]] *[[International Solar Alliance]] {{Div col end}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Solar power by country}} {{Renewable energy by country}} [[Category:Solar power by country| ]] [[Category:Renewable energy]] __FORCETOC__ __INDEX__
